title: How do foreigners feel on Diwali? - Quora

response.answer_text: How do foreigners feel? Let me tell you how I feel. I'm from Kerala. In Kerala all religious festivals are celebrated, I would say, just to the point it starts to become annoying. For Diwali diyas (lamps) are lit and houses decorated. We do burst crackers, but here is where we stop before it shatters your ear drum off. Temples and churches in Kerala used to compete to put forth the best fireworks during festivals, but after a string of disasters, the court has banned such a display of waste. I did my college in Bangalore, lived in a middle class locality, which also had it's mix of labour class, who worked primarily in construction. We would join in the festivities of Diwali, with our landlords, friends & neighbours, busting crackers and gulping down sweets! First day is always interesting, no let me correct that, first few hours of fire works are interesting. But by midnight it starts to get really annoying - ear shattering noise, eye-watering & suffocating smoke, drain clogging cracker wrappers, unexploded crackers among the pile etc. You wouldn't be able to make out good roads from an open manhole or gutter or drain because millions of wrappers strewn everywhere. You're afraid to step on an unexploded cracker & burning yourself. You're afraid you would fall into a gutter or drain! Don't ask me to explain the situation if it rains. By mid night on the first day, you would just want to shut the door and catch a few shut eye, just then your neighbour’s kid has woken up from his nap and started firing up reserve of those huge dynamite like crackers. We used to call them Atom bombs, because they literally shook the house foundations! This would continue for a few hours and when he stops, some other, this time fully grown ass adult, starts. I was a paramedical student and used to check my blood pressure during these 3 days of festivities. All of us didn't realise that the sound & smoke raised our BP considerably. Another important fact that surprised us was that most families spent a good chunk of their month’s revenue on these things that lasts a few seconds and goes up in smoke and sound. Mind numbingly, even the poor day-wage labourer, spent all his earnings on bursting crackers. In the weeks after the festivities, we used to see increased cases of pulmonary illnesses, bronchial infections, asthmatic aggravations etc. My friends started playing a game during those sleepless nights. They would try guessing the cost of a cracker by the noise it generates! When a cracker goes up in smoke, they would say ‘there goes his 20 rupees in smoke, there goes his 50 rupees down the drain’!! It was a game, but that was the reality. All that money, up in smoke in a few days.

Interesting A2A! I love that almost all religions have a festival that celebrates light, the triumph of that which is luminous over that which is dark. When I got to India I found Diwali to be scintillating and exciting -- going around the house of my friend with his family, leaving rupees in nooks and corners, lighting candles and invoking Lakshmi to bless it so that the following year may be prosperous; the lamps and lights, the firecrackers, the joy and the merry-making -- it was all very magical and I enjoyed it fiercely. Years later my son was born on the day before Ganesh Chaturthi. A friend who came to visit brought a small, grey stone statue of Ganesh that we kept on the night stand next to a large, cream-colored candle scented vanilla. We felt that our son being born so close to the puja was auspicious. A few days later, the celebrations for Diwali began. I remember going out on the bike -- sleep-deprived, getting used to being a father -- in search for fresh fruits and vegetables, groceries and detergent, when some wayward kids exploded a big firecracker right next to my bike. If it were a cartoon, I would have leaped in the air and landed on the roof of the house next to me. It being reality, I stopped the bike, my blood-boiling, a maddening buzzing in my ears, "Hey! adu sari illa! -- that's not okay!" I yelled at them. They snickered and sidled away. Anyway, they knew they weren't doing anything wrong -- it was almost diwali, and this is what they did every year -- played with firecrackers; sometimes, at the expense of hapless passersby. In the following days more and more firecrackers were lit and exploded, and our evenings, from being spent quietly and peacefully, exploring the new mysterious and adorable addition to our family, became a tense and jittery expectation for the next ear-numbing and brain-blasting explosion. So to answer your question, when I was alone, traveling and experiencing India, it was wonderful. Years later, when I was a family man, it was nightmarish.

That will be my 1st Diwali overseas in my life! I am going to miss my mom and sis in law’ s cooking. In addition , i will be missing visiting all my sis in law’s families [ i am in good terms with all the in laws and we always have big functions everywhere]. I will be missing my two nephews whom i bring them to Little India and shop with them their clothes and fireworks (mathaappu). I miss the time where both my nephews make me walk over 20 shops just to choose a freaking set of clothes. Thats how choosy children are! But I enjoy those process and memories which they give me. Boys are boys always! Last Diwali, I did celebration in my own house in Yishun. I used to wake up early on Diwali, throw some turmeric water at my doorstep and draw some simple rangoli with coloured powders. After which I would water the Tulsi plant and do prayers to Tulsi plant. I would hang mango leaves outside my corridor gate. Then I would have boiled milk. I would do some vegetarian cooking and make kesari and would lay all the food on a banana leaf in front of the altars and start doing my prayers. Saambraani and incest smell would fill my own house. After which I would head to my parents house and after which to my brother house where the little ones eagerly waiting for the arrival of their lovely aunty. Today, everything is a memory. Diwali in Singapore is a major occasion. I am happy that I was born in a country where Diwali is declared as a public holiday and have great emphasize is placed on celebarations Anyway, to ward away the yearnings, we, volunteers of Sri Venkateshwara Temple, Helensburg, NSW, Australia will be carrying out Diwali celebration from 2pm to 9pm on Saturday 14th Oct. I am not sure how many readers from Sydney are reading this. We have done our advertisement on various media platforms. If you do not wish to pay $50, you can just come and feel the Diwali atmosphere.  Catch us there. If you are new to Sydney, then this might an excellent time for you to get to know more Indian people here :)
